ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Live lecture (recorded and uploaded to canvas immediately afterwards) with instructor office hours and TA office hours
Optional instructor office hours which sometimes focus more on concepts than problems (a huge benefit, really helps with understanding the course)!
I personally used a combo of recorded and live lectures
peer tutors office hours, professor office hours
live virtual lecture that was recorded
I didn't use them, but the live lectures were recorded for students to view later.
Lectures were held live and were recorded, and I mostly watched the recorded lectures.

In class discussions of example problems in breakout rooms

Office hours over Zoom

Slack Channel
N/A
Live virtual and recorded lectures, problem sets, office hours
Office hours with the ULA
breakout rooms, slack
Watching recorded lectures was also an option.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Learned the theory behind limits, differentiation, and integration; manifolds, etc

I learned so much - I can't even list it all here! I came in as a student who was lost in Math 225, expecting to be equally lost in this, just trying to get a prerequisite out of the way so I can be even more lost in Math 300 and complete the B.S. requirement for the applied math major. I was wrong! Prof. Neitzke is a natural teacher, and has a way of explaining abstract concepts (manifolds, tangent spaces, differential forms - you name it) in a way that's comprehensible to those who prefer more concrete structures. While I don't necessarily think I'll go into the more abstract side of math, this course has given me a much better understanding of it - and I think everyone interested in math (even if only its applications like CS/engineering/physics/econ) should take this course after linear algebra - it gives you a much better understanding of the underlying structures of the mathematical tools you use in your field.
Great class for becoming more comfortable with proofs and theory based math classes

The formal definition of a limit, derivatives, inverse and implicit function theorems, what manifolds are, differential forms and Stokes' theorem. For the first half of the class, we wrote more proofs; then we ran out of time and did more calculations, although still for things that could make you think.
I learned about more difficult linear algebra.
Deeper understanding of differentiation and integration in higher dimensions.

I feel like I gained a much better theoretical understanding of the concepts in Math 120, and honestly, gained a huge appreciation for topics from linear algebra. I think a lot of students that take 120 are just taught the mechanics of solving problems, which really does make sense for most people, but this class was very interesting as someone who was interested in how multivariable calculus works. On top of that, I feel like I was set up for some higher level analysis courses, since we spent a good amount of time on topics like the delta-epsilon definition of continuity. This was also my first proof-writing course, and while I think the content leaned computation, I feel fairly ready to continue to 300-level math classes.
Calculus on Manifolds, Stoke's Theorem, differential forms, theory of limits.
Calculus in R^n! (and gained some proof-writing and proof-reading skills in the process)
Math
I learned about limits, integration, manifolds, differential forms, Generalized Stokes Theorem and more in this class.
I expanded my knowledge of multi variable calculus from Math 120 by applying methods from linear algebra.
Vector analysis and manifolds. They are cool.
I did learn more about proof-writing and the intuition behind things learned in 120.
Understanding of manifolds, vector calculus
Calculus on manifolds and proofs
Reinforcement and extension of multivariable calculus
A good understanding of vector calculus.

The first half of the course formalizes the definitions of limits and derivatives in higher dimensions and introduces the inverse and implicit function theorems. The second half focuses on manifolds in R^n and differential forms.
Developed knowledge of multivariable calculus significantly and feel more comfortable using multivariable calculus and linear in tandom.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Honestly the only weakness is the difficulty of the material but that isn't really the fault of the course there are so many resources to help and it is definitely manageable

Strength: Prof. Neitzke taught it this term. Weakness: he doesn't teach it every term. Seriously.

After spring break last semester, when everything moved online, I had the opportunity to start watching his lectures for 225, whether live or in the media library for the class. I was fine in my 225 lectures prior to spring break - between the lectures, the book, YouTube, and the peer tutors, I was starting to get a conceptual grasp on the field - but things really started clicking when I got the opportunity to watch his lectures. 250 was no different.

I think what helps is that he shows lower-dimensional examples of the concepts he's teaching and then explains things that can generalize (e.g. wedge product) and things that can't (e.g. cross product), so I'd call that a strength. I can't really think of any weaknesses; I really enjoyed the course. (I would only maybe say that midnight deadlines are a bit rough, since in a normal year we theoretically have all night to work on a pset before submitting it the next morning - and inevitably most of us are going to wait until the last day. While the midnight deadline helps us get a bit more sleep, it definitely hurt my pset/midterm grades, so I'd probably suggest moving the deadline to before class starts. But not a huge deal - and certainly not unique to this class - as midnight deadlines have become the standard for virtual assignments, for better or worse).

Strengths: The lecture format of introducing a definition and then immediately giving a more tangible example was helpful for learning, as were the color-coded and neat lecture notes. Also, Professor Neitzke. In this weird semester, he made every effort to be accessible for answering questions. He tries to meet students where they're at with their understanding of the material. He plans ahead for lectures, explains concepts clearly, and has contagious enthusiasm for the content. 

Weaknesses: The pacing could be a bit uneven, although it didn't leave you unprepared for tests. Solutions to more problem sets would have been nice.
It was clearly taught and made sense for most students. It was a good class, although the learning curve was steep at times. Cannot think of too many weaknesses.

The problem set grading was slow, so we often handed in 3-4 problem sets before getting the first one back. It would have been helpful so we could've gotten more feedback on proof-writing and apply that to subsequent problem sets.

The class was clearly prepared well in advance, and I really can't place enough emphasis on the coherency of the class. Not only were lectures recorded, but notes were posted and office hours were held regularly, so I really got the impression that students were meant to succeed. The homework problems were interesting, pretty straightforward if you listen to the lectures, and prepare students really well for tests. As someone who gets super stressed about tests, the take home tests were a blessing. Honesty, I looked forward to Math 250 every morning, and left the class with nothing but positive feelings. There was also a really natural flow to the material, and the entrance of differential forms felt natural by the end. My only incredibly minor suggestion would be to spend a day on some of the derivative laws we all know and love

Professor Neitzke was super responsive, he was always available on Slack and through his email which made this normally tough class bearable. There were also office hours, though I'd prefer to have more. He is also a very entertaining and knowledgeable lecturer and I got alot from attending class.
Weakness: virtually zero feedback from student graders on homework assignments - just points off and not even a hint at what went wrong.

Strengths: well-organized lectures, Professor encouraged class participation, Professor presented material in very understandable ways (often providing both the formal definitions and some intuition, and always following with examples), use of slack to easily communicate with classmates and Professors, reasonable and engaging psets

Weaknesses: pset grading was occasionally a bit slow, but not a big deal
There should be more time dedicated to learning how to write a proof.

I enjoyed the content of this course, and Professor Neitzke was a great and very clear lecturer. The problems sets were nicely sized and reinforced the material well, however I would say the grading was very strict in this class, sometimes unnecessarily. Otherwise, Professor Neitzke and our TA both clearly cared about our learning and were very available.
Professor Neitzke went out of his way to make sure that we had the most assistance possible when seeking help through abundant office hours and a very helpful Slack channel.
Professor was great

Professor Neitzke is definitely approachable and cares but some things in the course are glossed over unless people ask questions. I liked Richards office hours and found them very helpful but wish we did more problems in class. I also think there could have been more commentary given/support on homework and proof-writing. I wish we had an answer key to the psets prior to the first exam in order to have a better idea of what was required.

Overall I thought Professor Neitzke was a great instructor and ran the course very well. He was very accessible for answering student questions both during lecture and at other times. Part of the difficulty of the course was simply due to it being a virtual semester. A review session before the midterm and before the final may have been helpful.
Professor was great!

A weakness of the course is the grading. We didn't receive grades fast enough to get a good sense of how well we were doing in the class or for which subjects to study harder. Also, problem sets weren't graded and turned back to us before we took the final and midterms, so for problems I was unsure about I couldn't verify if I was doing them correctly. A strength would be the professor's organization and lecture notes. Wow, the categorization and "remarks," "theorems," and "example" headings were really helpful, and it even changed the way I take notes for stem classes.

The strength is definitely the professor. Prof. Neitzke is one of the most committed professors I have ever had, period. He stays after class every time anyone has a question and makes himself available for people to ask questions. I feel very lucky to have been in his class.
The lectures and notes, as well as the office hours, were very helpful.

The course provides good intuition and diverse examples for the concepts it teaches, which helps with understanding the material and how to apply it. However, the course was not very formal when discussing the theory of manifolds and differential forms (e.g., some results were stated without proof) and the problem sets were typically computation-heavy for these topics, which does not really help students who are looking for practice with approaching and writing proofs. While providing intuition is necessary, I feel like the course could be improved by making the material on manifolds and differential forms just as rigorous as the material on limits and derivatives (for which most, if not all, results were proved).
Prof is very engaging and enthusiastic, unfortunately, I felt like the class wasnt very into it or the virtual setting decreased participation.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Recording the lectures and uploading on canvas was great! The lectures were engaging and worked well in a virtual setting where Professor Neitzke screen-shared his iPad.

Success: engaging lectures; drawing things out by hand instead of clicking through a PowerPoint (so we can keep up with the pace and take notes); keeping the students engaged during lectures for those who were there; and for those students like me, who inevitably slept through the lecture each morning and watched the recordings later, making lectures interesting and engaging enough to where I could watch multiple and not get tired of them. Seriously - while other course's recordings/live lectures were long, drawn out, and boring (often causing me to set them to 1.5x speed to get through), I would plan to sit down and watch one lecture for this course to stay on track, but instead get excited for the next topic and watch 2-3 lectures at a time. I'm not entirely sure how, but this class was engaging and it's the only course where I feel I did not lose any engagement learning online instead of in person.

Weaknesses: Just in general, I don't think sending students to breakout rooms to discuss examples is particularly helpful. This course's material can be challenging, and unfortunately in an online environment the instructor can only monitor one group at a time. Fortunately, Prof. Neitzke noticed this and abandoned the idea, making the latter classes even more engaging than those at the beginning (as if that was even possible).

Having recorded lectures and posted notes on canvas was great! Virtual office hours were done well, both by the peer tutor and the professor. Having the Slack channels for quick questions was also helpful.
The slack channel was nice, even if I didn't use it that much

Recording lectures definitely helped for people with time zone differences. Office hours ended up conflicting with other classes and it was difficult for me personally to go to all the office hours I wanted to, as all the other classes also wanted to schedule office hours and sections at times that was suitable for people from different time zones.

I really think this class was built around the pandemic very well. The live lectures kept things interesting and made sure students who could attend would stay engaged, while the recorded lectures and clear notes made the material accessible for people in different time zones. (I would imagine) the take home exams also kept things simple for people in other time zones.

The recorded lectures functioned very well, and Professor Neitzke did a great job organizing and presenting his notes, and posting the PDFs of his notes after class. There were occasional delays in PDF and lecture uploads, but not significantly. I was pleased with how the course was run from a COVID perspective.
I enjoyed the way that live lectures had brief sessions of breakout rooms where we could discuss example problems. I also relied heavily on the Slack chat throughout the semester.
Online lectures were super clear
Professor Neitzke did a great job with the virtual lecture including having some breakout rooms, leaving time for questions, and his online notes.
Recording lectures was helpful for when it was not always possible to attend live. Slack was also helpful for asking questions outside lectures and office hours.
Having the lectures recorded for later use was very useful. Also, the Slack was a very valuable resource.
I felt like attending lectures over Zoom and office hours were plenty to facilitate learning of the material of this course.
Take home exams worked well. The zoom setting wasnt great because lack of participation but maybe could be improved with a different group of students.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Professor Neitzke is AMAZING. Absolutely incredible. This is definitely the hardest math class I've taken so far at Yale (compared to 120 and 225) so be prepared to put in the work, and the concepts can get really confusing, but the class is really well-organized and helps you the entire way. Make sure you take this with a friend because working on psets by yourself would be terrible, but TA office hours are super, super helpful.

100% - super interesting for any math-inclined student (even those focused more on the applications like me). Great virtual course, quite engaging, and super accessible instructor. Can't recommend it enough!

Yes! I was terrified to take it but ended up surviving! Prof Neitzke was great! Lectures were interesting and topics well explained. Much preferred having take home exams and felt they were very fair. Homework takes time and often required some office hour help but was manageable and always relevant/helpful for the week's content.

Yes. It's very well taught, and the problem sets are thought-provoking without being overwhelming. If you're not experienced with math and proofs (I fall into this category), this course still provides plenty of resources to learn the content.

I would absolutely recommend this class if that person is math-oriented. But the class was definitely a jump from previous classes in terms of difficulty, so perhaps people not committed to math should not take it.

Yes. You usually have to take this for your major and don't have much choice, but the course was great. Neitzke it amazing. He was very available through Slack, after class, and office hours. The material can be pretty complicated, but Neitzke was really good at explaining things and answering questions in class. He was excited about the content and wanted to engage with us so we could understand it as best as we could. This is pretty rare given the past experience I have had with math professors here.

Take this class! Not only is Neitzke a fantastic professor, but the workload was really manageable. I took Math 222, and I was expecting to be behind the ball with proof writing, but the class really warms you into it. Besides a few curveball questions on PSETs, the homeworks were super reasonable and followed the lecture pretty directly. If you're looking to understand the mechanics you learned in Math 120 in a pretty chill way, this class is absolutely for you.

If this class is offered with Professor Neitzke again please take it. He is absolutely amazing, Yale is so lucky to have hired him last year. This subject is also incredibly interesting, if you have taken Math 120 you essentially can derive everything you learned from that class by the end of the semester. Really give you a better appreciation for mathematics.

I would only recommend this course after a strong proof-writing and linear algebra background. Contrary to the stated requirements, a basic course in linear algebra such as Math 222 is not enough. 

Great class if you have the right background though!

Yes, absolutely! Calculus in R^n is beautiful, and taking this more rigorous approach helps make this beauty apparent. The material is incredibly interesting, and makes me want to continue learning more math. Professor Neitzke presented the material in an engaging and comprehensible way, and his enthusiasm and energy definitely rubs off (which was good considering the class started at 9:25am EST). If you enjoy math at all, you should definitely try taking this class.
100%, Neitzke is one of the best math instructors I've had in my time at Yale and the content was well-organized and interesting.

Yes I would recommend this course, as I found the material covered very valuable in thinking about vector spaces more generally and having a good foundation of them. I also really liked Professor Neitzke -- he explains everything very clearly, and genuinely cares about the success of his students. I would say the problem sets are often tedious and one or two problems always requires the help of office hours, but our TA was very helpful. I did find the grading rather harsh, though. Otherwise, midterms and problems were fair.
I would recommend this course to anyone who would like to strengthen their proof-writing skills or gain knowledge of vector calculus for use in a field of interest.
Yes, Professor is good.
I think its a good introductory course to analysis and a good class overall. You need to be on top of things, which can be hard with online school, in order to really understand things, though.

Yes, if they are interested in learning about calculus for arbitrarily high dimensions or manifolds, if they generally enjoy proof based math, if they are interested in taking more analysis later on, or if they are interested in better understanding math that is relevant in high dimensional contexts.
Yes! It was a good intro to math proofs
Yes; it's hard but rewarding.
Yes, please take it under Prof. Neitzke!
Yes.

I would recommend this course to a student who is interested in learning the concepts (either out of curiosity or to just know that such concepts exist so that they aren't totally unfamiliar with them when they see them again in higher level math courses) but perhaps not at the highest level of rigor.
Yes, good conclusion to intro process to a math major and learning proof based math. If not interested in proofs, probably wouldnt recommend this course to that person
